bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 17, 1947

div1.p: Kean shares family news. He is glad to receive copies of Walter Reed's diplomas and describes Truby's visit. He is relieved to hear that Building No. 1, at Camp Lazear, will be preserved.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 17, 1947

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C. 17 June '47 19 " "

div1.p:
Mrs Kean and I have been away
on a charming visit to my old comrade
Col. Berl of World War I and on my return I find
an armful of mail including your interest-
ing letter of June 2nd with its inclosures
Also the excellent photographs of Major
Walter Reed's diplomas- Several of the signa-
tures on his M. D. from the University of Va.
were the same as on mine fifteen years
later, notably Dr. John Staige Davis in Prac
tice of Medicine and Dr- James C. Cabell
in Surgery. The picture of the Army Medical Museum
looks a little drawn out to the left- This is
evidently the South front and Reeds office
was on the S. E. Corner on the second floor- That
is when he became Librarian- Before that he was at the Army Med School on La. Avenue-
2-
Gen. Truby has been in Virginia for a couple
of weeks but not near Washington. He has
now come to Washington and is at Walter
Reed Hospital for a check over- This will
give him a convenient base to run around
and see his friends and he telephoned
today that he and Mrs. Truby would
come to see us tomorrow afternoon.
Gen Lawrence Reed will bring them in-
He has planned to go to the War Col-
lege (old Wash. Bks. to see if he can
locate the room in which Walter
Reed died. He will get the new Surg,
Gen. to send him down that he will
have due attention- I will see them
before I mail this letter and so
will add anything of interest that
he may tell me in a P. S..

closer.seg:
P. S. They came but later than we expected
them as they went first to see the Irelands
3
and did not get here until 5.15 and
Truby had to report back to the Hospital
at 6, pm- I found him looking very
well, tho. he drags his left leg a little-
But he got a good report from the Hospital
and has a blood pressure of 170 over 96
which they told him was very good for
his age. It is lower than mine which
was 180 over 115 to 120 when Dr. Healy
came to see me last Tuesday and
gave me my discharge as a patient.
He is a fine young man and we are all
pleased with him-
It seems to me that you have things well
started for the preservation of the building
at Camp Lazear- It is a lucky accident
that Dr. Finlay should have made some of
4
Ac
k
his experiments at Finca Son José as it
connects him with that locality in addi-
tion to the fact that Dr Finlay visited
Camp Lazear repeatedly to verify the diag-
noses of Reed's experimental cases-
I have been reading his experimental
cases and am quite impressed with
that of Rev. E. Urra S. J which he treated
at the pleasure From ‘La Asuncion’ which
I take to be the same as Finca San Jose
in “Los Quemados”- I am very curious
to know what your conclusion are as
to his claim that the limitations of
the Reed Board as to the limit of infection
power of the patient on the mosquito and
of the incubation period in men are too rigid-
His discussion of the work of the Board in his sons
book are very interesting- is waiting
Affectionately yours
J. R. Kean
